page.title: 01ADLINGTON / POTT SHRIGLEY
page.content: The designated block lies in the foot hills of the Pennines, rising from 300 feet in the west to 1200 feet in the east. The higher ground is moorland giving way to rough grazing and pasture as it falls to enclose Pott Shrigley village. A 900 foot ridge, called The Nab, rises steeply from Bollington encircling Pott Shrigley to the west so dividing it from Adlington Below the moors the land curves gently and a number of small streams flow through wooded cloughs to the river Dean. Natural woodland, mosly oak, ash sycamore and holly abounds. Fields in the east are bordered by stone walls but these are replaced by hedges in the lower lying west. The temperate climate is dominated by westerly winds. Rain on the hills is 50 to 60 inches annually. Temperatures are 60F in July and 37F in January.
